talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice:

item.para: Is the Minister aware of the 1969 study by the United States National Bureau of Standards which revealed that various components of commercial aircraft, including seat cushions, ceiling panels, draperies and plastic trays, when exposed to intense heat, give off highly toxic gases, lethal in impact on humans.

Is the Minister also aware that an eminent toxicologist, Dr G. Christopoulis, of Chicago, United States of America, reported in February of thisyear that, in studies of aircraft crashes, he had found that hydrogen cyanide and carbon monoxide gases were responsible for killing many passengers before the flames had reached them.

Will the Minister investigate methods of equipping future commercial aircraft with materials which are inert and non-flammable in the presence of intense heat, so as to increase the possibility of passenger survival in aircraft accidents.

question.para: Senator CAVANAGH-The Minister for Civil Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: The Department of Civil Aviation is aware of the work done by the Fire Research Section of the American National Bureau of Standards for the Federal Aviation Administration on the subject of smoke and gases produced by burning aircraft interior materials and is keeping in touch with this work and other industry developments.

Yes, the Department has received copies of newspaper reports referring to the findings of the chief toxicologist to the Cook County Coroner in relation to 2 aircraft accidents at Chicago last December. Further details have been requested from the American accident investigation authorities.

All known cabin interior furnishing materials meeting acceptable comfort standards emit some smoke and toxic gases when subjected to intense heat. The selection of suitable materials has always been a careful choice involving factors such as safety, comfort and cost. Interior design aspects such as weave, texture, colour, dye-ability and durability, particularly after repeated cleaning operations, are also considered.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister repre senting the Minister for Health, upon notice:

quote.para: Is the Minister aware that the administration of Queensland health services has reached an all-time low; if so, will the Minister take appropriate steps to ensure that Queensland is the first State investigated by any Commonwealth committee of inquiry into health factors generally.

question.para: Senator DOUGLASMcCLELLAND- The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: It is well known that Queensland has been able to spend less than other States per hospital bed to provide adequate staffing, working conditions, equipment and treatment standards overall thanother States and the Federal Territories. This is in part a legacy of some 20 years of discrimination in bed subsidy by previous governments. The policy until recent years was to give the full Commonwealth bed subsidy only for beds occupied by voluntarily insured patients. Because of the Queensland free hospital system most public patients do not have this insurance in Queensland. I shall request Dr Sax, Chairman of the Interim Committee on Hospitals and Health Services, to take Queensland's special needs into account when recommending Federal assistance to Stales. It will be recalled that our spokesman on Health and Welfare during the 1972 election campaign, now the Minister for Social Security, indicated that the benefit of proposed new rates of subsidy would amount to $22m per year for Queensland.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice:

item.para: What specific evidence can the Minister furnish to justify his public statement that some nursing homes are deliberately over-prescribing drugs to produce heavy sedation in patients to reduce the necessity to feed such patients and so to save money.
What are the names of nursing homes allegedly involved in this scandalous practice and of the medical practitioners who have prescribed the drugs.
What action has the Minister taken with regard to the charges which he has made.
Does the Minister agree that the great majority of nursing homes are well run, are ethically conducted, and provide a most valuable public service.

question.para: Senator DOUGLASMcCLELLAND- The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: A statement recorded in the Hansard report of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly for 26th

question.para: October 1971, alleged certain malpractices in nursing homes, particularly in relation to the over-sedating of patients and keeping them in bed to obtain the supplementary nursing homes benefit payable in respect of intensive nursing home care cases. Copies of 6 statutory declarations and one written statement referred to in the above case were made available to my Department. In addition a further 21 cases of alleged malpractices in nursing homes have been brought to the attention of my Department or myself since that date. 1 would add that late in 1971 the New South Wales Minister for Health, the Hon. A. H. Jago, M.L.A., did request a joint Commonwealth/State investigation of the allegations brought to the attention of the New South Wales Parliament. The previous Government declined this request.

item.para: It is not proposed to name individual nursing homes at this stage.

My Department has, at my instructions, commenced an investigation into the operation of nursing homes with particular attention being paid to those homes in which irregularities have been brought to my notice or to the notice of my Department.

I have frequently stated that the majority of nursing homes are well run and conducted, and provide a most valuable public service. My statements regarding the unsatisfactory operation of nursing homes referred to a small minority of nursing homes only and this was clearly stated by me.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Docs the Government propose to provide the contraceptive pill as a free medical benefit to those persons who apply, in due form.
Will the Government have the National Health and Medical Research Council provide a comprehensive statement as to the known side effects due to the constant use of the pill.

question.para: Senator DOUGLASMcCLELLAND- The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

item.para: Certain oral contraceptives became available as pharmaceutical benefits on 1st February 1972; thus between 1st February and 31st March 1 month's supply of these products was obtainable, on a prescription, free of charge by persons having an entitlement under the Pensioner Medical Service, for 50c by persons with an entitlement under the Subsidised Health Benefits Plan and for a patient contribution of $1 by other persons. As from 1st April 1973 2 months' supporal contraceptives has been available for the appropriate patient contribution.

question.para: Drug Evaluation Committee has distributed to all doctors and drug companies, information dealing with oral contraceptives. Drug Infor mation Circular No. 1 (Oral Contraceptives), September 1969, and Drug Information Circular No. 2 (Oral Contraceptives and Thromboembolic Disease), May 1970 provide doctors and drug companies with a comprehensive statement on contraindications, warnings, precautions, laboratory data and known and suspected side effects associated with oral contraceptives. All companies marketing systemic contraceptives are required to include these data and other prescribing information in package inserts for the medical and allied professions as well as a less technical insert containing information for the patient. A copy of Drug Information Circulars Nos 1 and 2 can be provided if the honourable senator so desires.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation, upon notice:

quote.para: What initiatives, if any, have been taken by the internal airline companies to replace their turbo-prop aircraft, now in use and servicing smaller airports, with jets.

question.para: Senator CAVANAGH-The Minister for Civil Aviation has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: MacRobertson Miller Airline Services, the ATI subsidiary operating in Western Australia, has withdrawn the turbo-prop F27 and now operates the medium twin jet F28 on the air routes in Western Australia and through to Darwin.
